elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig1">
<ce:label>Fig. 1</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">(a) The op<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> bridging modes in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>; (b) the Sm(III) atoms are bridged by the op<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> groups into 2D layer parallel to [0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0]; (c) the (3,4,5,6)-connected five-nodal 2D topology (the green balls are the Sm atoms; the red, yellow and blue balls represent the μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-, μ<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>-, and μ<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>-bridging op groups, respectively). (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 1  (a) The op2- bridging modes in 1; (b) the Sm(III) atoms are bridged by the op2- groups into 2D layer parallel to [010]; (c) the (3,4,5,6)-connected five-nodal 2D topology (the green balls are the Sm atoms; the red, yellow and blue balls represent the μ3-, μ4-, and μ4-bridging op groups, respectively). (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig2">
<ce:label>Fig. 2</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">(a) Two-dimensional structure and (b) the (3,4)-connected topological network of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr2"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 2  (a) Two-dimensional structure and (b) the (3,4)-connected topological network of 2 and 3.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig3">
<ce:label>Fig. 3</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">(a) Two-dimensional structure in <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>; (b) three-dimensional framework with the lattice water filling in the channels along <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>-axis; (c) the four-connected topological subunit; (d) the (4,5)-connected topological network (the gray dots indicating four-connected mp nodes and the green knots showing the five-connected La nodes). (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr3"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 3  (a) Two-dimensional structure in 4; (b) three-dimensional framework with the lattice water filling in the channels along b-axis; (c) the four-connected topological subunit; (d) the (4,5)-connected topological network (the gray dots indicating four-connected mp nodes and the green knots showing the five-connected La nodes). (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig4">
<ce:label>Fig. 4</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">(a) Two-dimensional structure in <ce:bold>5</ce:bold>; (b) three-dimensional framework; (c) the four-connected topological subunit (the red balls are op ligands and the green balls suggest the La atoms); (d) the (4,5)-connected topological network (the red dots indicating four-connected op nodes and the green knots showing the five-connected La nodes). (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr4"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 4  (a) Two-dimensional structure in 5; (b) three-dimensional framework; (c) the four-connected topological subunit (the red balls are op ligands and the green balls suggest the La atoms); (d) the (4,5)-connected topological network (the red dots indicating four-connected op nodes and the green knots showing the five-connected La nodes). (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)

<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">The photoluminescence emission spectra for complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>

</ce:figure>

elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

Four novel topological nets of lanthanide frameworks have been hydrothermally synthesized. Compound 1 exhibits novel (3,4,5,6)-connected 2D five-nodal topological net, compounds 2 and 3 show (3,4)-connected V2O5 topologies, compound 4 displays the (4,5)-connected 3D topological net, and compound 5 shows the (4,5)-connected 3D four-nodal topological network.

elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Four novel topological nets of lanthanide metal-organic frameworks: [Sm2(op)3(H2O)] n  (1), {Ln2(op)2(ox)(H2O)4]⋅H2O} n  (Ln=La, 2; Sm, 3), {[La2(mp)2(ox)(H2O)4]  ⋅  2H2O} n  (4), [La2(op)2(mp)(H2O)4] n  (5) (op=o-phthalate, mp=m-phthalate, and ox=oxalate), have been hydrothermally synthesized and characterized. Compound 1 exhibits novel (3,4,5,6)-connected five-nodal two-dimensional net, compound 2 and 3 show the (3,4)-connected V2O5 topologies, compound 4 has the (4,5)-connected topological net, and compound 5 shows the (4,5)-connected four-nodal three-dimensional network. Photoluminescent analyses of 1 and 3 show strong blue emission in the solid state at room temperature.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The assembly of lanthanide complexes has attracted much more attention in recent years for the rapidly expanding field of crystal engineering of high dimensionality metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) due to their various network topologies as well as their potential application as functional materials . Up to date, many high dimensionality metal-organic frameworks represent themselves as realistic targets of inorganic compounds or minerals in nature with topological nets . Recently, particular attention has been attracted to the use of unsymmetrical building blocks with different connectivities to generate unique topological nets. For example, nets containing both three- and four-connected node form networks such as (3,4)-connected characteristic boracite net, ReO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, and Pt<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>; and other nets consisting of mix-connected nodes form topologies such as (3,6)-connected rutile net, (4,6)-connected α-Al<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> net, and (4,8)-connected CaF<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> net . Lanthanide ions possess fascinating coordination geometry, interesting luminescence and magnetic properties, so they can be used to construct intriguing structures with special properties in material science, for example, superconductors, magnetic materials, luminescence probes and catalysts . By contrast, the progress of the analogous chemistry of lanthanide metals has been slow , which may be attributed, at least partially, to the tendency of these ions for high coordination that favors the formation of condensed structures and causes difficulty in controlling the synthetic reactions. Although the variety of the coordination sphere of lanthanide ion makes design difficult, the multiplicity makes the f-block metal ions fascinating for the discovery of new and unusual network topologies . In this contribution, we present new mixed node topological nets of lanthanide metal-organic frameworks: [Sm<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(op)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]<ce:italic>

elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The assembly of lanthanide complexes has attracted much more attention in recent years for the rapidly expanding field of crystal engineering of high dimensionality metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) due to their various network topologies as well as their potential application as functional materials . Up to date, many high dimensionality metal-organic frameworks represent themselves as realistic targets of inorganic compounds or minerals in nature with topological nets . Recently, particular attention has been attracted to the use of unsymmetrical building blocks with different connectivities to generate unique topological nets. For example, nets containing both three- and four-connected node form networks such as (3,4)-connected characteristic boracite net, ReO3, and Pt3O4; and other nets consisting of mix-connected nodes form topologies such as (3,6)-connected rutile net, (4,6)-connected α-Al2O3 net, and (4,8)-connected CaF2 net . Lanthanide ions possess fascinating coordination geometry, interesting luminescence and magnetic properties, so they can be used to construct intriguing structures with special properties in material science, for example, superconductors, magnetic materials, luminescence probes and catalysts . By contrast, the progress of the analogous chemistry of lanthanide metals has been slow , which may be attributed, at least partially, to the tendency of these ions for high coordination that favors the formation of condensed structures and causes difficulty in controlling the synthetic reactions. Although the variety of the coordination sphere of lanthanide ion makes design difficult, the multiplicity makes the f-block metal ions fascinating for the discovery of new and unusual network topologies . In this contribution, we present new mixed node topological nets of lanthanide metal-organic frameworks: [Sm2(op)3(H2O)] n  (1), {[Ln2(op)2(ox)(H2O)4]⋅H2O} n  (Ln=La, 2; Sm, 3), {[La2(mp)2(ox)(H2O)4]⋅2H2O} n  (4), [La2(op)2(mp)(H2O)4] n  (5) (op= o-phthalate, mp= m-phthalate, and ox=oxalate). Compound 1 exhibits novel five-nodal (3,4,5,6)-connected two-dimensional topological net, compound 2 and 3 have (3,4)-connected V2O5 topologies, compound 4 displays the (4,5)-connected three-dimensional topological net , and compound 5 shows the (4,5)-connected topological network.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials and methods

All chemicals of reagent grade were commercially available and used without further purification. Elemental analyses were performed using a Perkin-Elmer 2400 CHNS/O analyzer. The infrared spectrum of KBr pellets in the range 4000-400cm-1 was recorded using a Nicolet AVATAR-370 spectrophotometer. All the excitation and emission spectra were measured with an Aminco Bowman Series 2 instrument with a xenon arc lamp as the excitation light source for the solid-state samples at room temperature.

elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallography

Crystallographic data for 1-5 were collected at room temperature on a Bruker Smart CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ =0.71073Å) by ω scan mode. shelxl-97 programs were used for structure solution and refinement. All the complexes were solved by Direct Methods. All non-hydrogen atoms were finally refined with anisotropic displacement parameters by full-matrix least-squares techniques, and hydrogen atoms with isotropic displacement parameters. The hydrogen atoms associated with carbon atoms were generated geometrically, and the H2O hydrogen atoms of compound 4 were located from the difference Fourier synthesis. The relevant crystal data and the experimental conditions along with the final parameters are summarized in  . Selected interatomic distances and bond angles are given in   .

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Synthesis of the complexes</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">We carried out the reactions of dicarboxylatic acid with lanthanide oxides under hydrothermal condition to construct novel topological network species, and five lanthanide metal-organic complexes suitable for single crystal X-ray diffraction were isolated successfully (
<ce:float-anchor refid="sch1"></ce:float-anchor>). The reaction of <ce:italic>o</ce:italic>-phthalic acid and Sm<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> yielded compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> holding (3,4,5,6)-connected two-dimensional five-nodal topological net, and the reactions of <ce:italic>o</ce:italic>-phthalic acid and Ln<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (Ln<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>La, Sm) in the present of oxalic acid generated the compounds <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> showing (3,4)-connected topologies. When the reaction of La<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> and <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>-phthalic acid was run in the present of oxalic acid, compound <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> presenting the novel (4,5)-connected three-dimensional topological net, was isolated in 35% yield. However, when similar reactions were performed by using Ln<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, <ce:italic>o</ce:italic>-phthalic and <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>-phthalic acid, to synthesize La/op/mp coordination polymer, only uncharacterized precipitates were obtained. Interestingly, when the above-mentioned reaction was finished with the mixture of La<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, La(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>-phthalic acid, and <ce:italic>o</ce:italic>-phthalic acid, compound <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> with the (4,5)-connected three-dimensional four-nodal topological structure, was isolated in 30% yield, which may result from the sensitive effect of lanthanide ions for pH value favoring the crystalline products suitable for single crystal X-ray diffraction. Herein it showed from the above-prepared compounds that the variety of organic bridging ligands as the connectors would result in the different topological nets by the self-assembly reaction, which may offer some suggestions for materials scientists to design and synthesize novel topological structures by simple bridging organic ligands acting as the connectors and metal ions as the nodes.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Synthesis of the complexes

We carried out the reactions of dicarboxylatic acid with lanthanide oxides under hydrothermal condition to construct novel topological network species, and five lanthanide metal-organic complexes suitable for single crystal X-ray diffraction were isolated successfully ( ). The reaction of o-phthalic acid and Sm2O3 yielded compound 1 holding (3,4,5,6)-connected two-dimensional five-nodal topological net, and the reactions of o-phthalic acid and Ln2O3 (Ln=La, Sm) in the present of oxalic acid generated the compounds 2 and 3 showing (3,4)-connected topologies. When the reaction of La2O3 and m-phthalic acid was run in the present of oxalic acid, compound 4 presenting the novel (4,5)-connected three-dimensional topological net, was isolated in 35% yield. However, when similar reactions were performed by using Ln2O3, o-phthalic and m-phthalic acid, to synthesize La/op/mp coordination polymer, only uncharacterized precipitates were obtained. Interestingly, when the above-mentioned reaction was finished with the mixture of La2O3, La(NO3)3, m-phthalic acid, and o-phthalic acid, compound 5 with the (4,5)-connected three-dimensional four-nodal topological structure, was isolated in 30% yield, which may result from the sensitive effect of lanthanide ions for pH value favoring the crystalline products suitable for single crystal X-ray diffraction. Herein it showed from the above-prepared compounds that the variety of organic bridging ligands as the connectors would result in the different topological nets by the self-assembly reaction, which may offer some suggestions for materials scientists to design and synthesize novel topological structures by simple bridging organic ligands acting as the connectors and metal ions as the nodes.

elements.clean_text:
Description of the crystal structure

Structure of [Sm2(op)3(H2O)] n  (1)

Single crystal X-ray structural analyses revealed that 1 crystallizes in monoclinic space group P2(1)/c, and 2 and 3 are isomorphic and crystallize in monoclinic, space group C2/c. compounds 1-3 feature as two-dimensional layers. Compounds 4 and 5 crystallize in monoclinic, space group C2/c and Cc, respectively, holding three-dimensional frameworks.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The asymmetric unit cell of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> consists of three anionic op<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands, two Sm(III) atoms and one coordinated water molecule, which is isomorphic with other lanthanide species in previous report . Sm1 atom is surrounded by eight oxygen atoms from five op<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands and one coordinated water molecule, and Sm2 atom is surrounded by nine oxygen atoms from six op<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands with distances of Sm–O bond ranging from 2.316 to 2.885<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, similar to other related Ln–O distances, in which op<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands serve as different μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-bridge and μ<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>-bridges (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>a). Sm(III) atoms are bridged by op<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands into 2D layer parallel to [0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0] plane (b). Remarkably, the framework of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits interesting topology. The op<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands and Sm(III) atoms can be considered as three-, four-, four-, five-, and six-connected nodes. As a result, compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits the (3,4,5,6)-connected five-nodal 2D topology (c). The net can be described by the Schläfli symbol of (4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>;6)(4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>;6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>;6<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>)(4<ce:sup loc="post">7</ce:sup>;6<ce:sup loc="post">7</ce:sup>;8) . The vertex symbol calculation was done using TOPOS4 . The five-nodal 2D topology is unreported in literature and the net of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is unprecedented.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The asymmetric unit cell of 1 consists of three anionic op2- ligands, two Sm(III) atoms and one coordinated water molecule, which is isomorphic with other lanthanide species in previous report . Sm1 atom is surrounded by eight oxygen atoms from five op2- ligands and one coordinated water molecule, and Sm2 atom is surrounded by nine oxygen atoms from six op2- ligands with distances of Sm-O bond ranging from 2.316 to 2.885Å, similar to other related Ln-O distances, in which op2- ligands serve as different μ3-bridge and μ4-bridges ( a). Sm(III) atoms are bridged by op2- ligands into 2D layer parallel to [010] plane (b). Remarkably, the framework of 1 exhibits interesting topology. The op2- ligands and Sm(III) atoms can be considered as three-, four-, four-, five-, and six-connected nodes. As a result, compound 1 exhibits the (3,4,5,6)-connected five-nodal 2D topology (c). The net can be described by the Schläfli symbol of (42;6)(44;62)2(46;64)(47;67;8) . The vertex symbol calculation was done using TOPOS4 . The five-nodal 2D topology is unreported in literature and the net of 1 is unprecedented.

The asymmetric unit of compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> contains one Sm(III) atom, one op<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand, one-half oxalate group, two coordinated water molecules and one lattice aqua. The Sm(III) atom is surrounded by eight O atoms, of which two come from the coordinated water, two come from one oxalate group and the rest come from op<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands. The Sm–O bond lengths range from 2.417 to 2.603<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, which are similar to those found in other Sm(III) complexes . In the structure of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, one carboxylate group of op<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand serves as bidentate chelating mode, whereas the other acts as bidentate bridging/chelating mode. As a result, each of the op<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> acts as μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-bridge jointing three metal atoms, and each of the metal atoms also links three op<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> organic groups, into a one-dimensional chain along the <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>-axis direction. The resulting chains are bridged by ox<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> groups into 2D sheet parallel to [0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1] (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>a).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Structures of {[Ln2(op)2(ox)(H2O)4]⋅H2O} n  (Ln=La, 2; Sm, 3)

For 2 and 3, only the structure of 3 is described in detail because of 2 and 3 being isostructural. The asymmetric unit of compound 3 contains one Sm(III) atom, one op2- ligand, one-half oxalate group, two coordinated water molecules and one lattice aqua. The Sm(III) atom is surrounded by eight O atoms, of which two come from the coordinated water, two come from one oxalate group and the rest come from op2- ligands. The Sm-O bond lengths range from 2.417 to 2.603Å, which are similar to those found in other Sm(III) complexes . In the structure of 3, one carboxylate group of op2- ligand serves as bidentate chelating mode, whereas the other acts as bidentate bridging/chelating mode. As a result, each of the op2- acts as μ3-bridge jointing three metal atoms, and each of the metal atoms also links three op2- organic groups, into a one-dimensional chain along the b-axis direction. The resulting chains are bridged by ox2- groups into 2D sheet parallel to [001] ( a).

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">From topological view, the sheet can be considered as the (3,4)-connected topological network (b), in which the op<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands and Sm atom function as three- and four-connected nodes, respectively, and the oxalate ligands can be represented simply as links between the Sm nodes. The (3,4)-connected topological network can be described using the Schläfli symbol of (4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>;6<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>;8)(4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>;6), with the vertex symbol or long symbol of (4.4.6) and (4.6.4.6.*.*) for the three- and four-connected nodes, respectively. The (3,4)-connected (4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>;6<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>;8)(4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>;6) topological network is similar to that of V<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: From topological view, the sheet can be considered as the (3,4)-connected topological network (b), in which the op2- ligands and Sm atom function as three- and four-connected nodes, respectively, and the oxalate ligands can be represented simply as links between the Sm nodes. The (3,4)-connected topological network can be described using the Schläfli symbol of (42;63;8)(42;6), with the vertex symbol or long symbol of (4.4.6) and (4.6.4.6.*.*) for the three- and four-connected nodes, respectively. The (3,4)-connected (42;63;8)(42;6) topological network is similar to that of V2O5.

<ce:section-title>Structure of {[La<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(mp)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(ox)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The asymmetric unit of compound <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> contains one La(III) atom, one mp<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand, one-half oxalate group, two coordinated water molecules and one lattice aqua. The central La(III) ion exhibits a square antiprism geometry, surrounded by eight oxygen atoms, of which two come from the coordinated water molecules, two come from one oxalate ligand and four come from four mp ligands. The distances La–O bond range from 2.418 to 2.619<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, which are comparable to those in the related La–carboxylate complexes . The mp ligand in <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> acts as a μ<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>-bridge linking four metal ions through its four carboxylate O atoms and each metal ion connects four ligands to form a square lattice layers (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>a). The layers are interlinked by oxalate ligands into porous 3D metal-organic framework with the lattice water filling in the channels along the <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>-axis (b). Topological analyses show that the MOFs consist of four-connected subunits (c). After simplifying the oxalate as links between the metal nodes, the four-connected subunits are held together by the μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-oxalate bridges to generate a new (4,5)-connected topology (d), where μ<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>-bridging op ligands act as four-connected nodes and the metal atoms serve as five-connected nodes. The topological network can be described by the Schläfli symbol of (4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>;6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)(4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>;6<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>.8<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>), the vertex symbol or long symbol of [4.4.4.4.6(2).6(3)][4.4.4.4.6.6.6(2).6(2).8(13).8(13)], and coordination sequences of (4, 12, 27, 45, 73, 114, 147, 197, 271, 308) for the four-connected nodes and (5, 12, 26, 49, 75, 108, 157, 203, 250, 326) for the five-connected nodes, respectively. This topology represents a (4,5)-connected network .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Structure of {[La2(mp)2(ox)(H2O)4]⋅2H2O} n  (4)

The asymmetric unit of compound 4 contains one La(III) atom, one mp2- ligand, one-half oxalate group, two coordinated water molecules and one lattice aqua. The central La(III) ion exhibits a square antiprism geometry, surrounded by eight oxygen atoms, of which two come from the coordinated water molecules, two come from one oxalate ligand and four come from four mp ligands. The distances La-O bond range from 2.418 to 2.619Å, which are comparable to those in the related La-carboxylate complexes . The mp ligand in 4 acts as a μ4-bridge linking four metal ions through its four carboxylate O atoms and each metal ion connects four ligands to form a square lattice layers ( a). The layers are interlinked by oxalate ligands into porous 3D metal-organic framework with the lattice water filling in the channels along the b-axis (b). Topological analyses show that the MOFs consist of four-connected subunits (c). After simplifying the oxalate as links between the metal nodes, the four-connected subunits are held together by the μ2-oxalate bridges to generate a new (4,5)-connected topology (d), where μ4-bridging op ligands act as four-connected nodes and the metal atoms serve as five-connected nodes. The topological network can be described by the Schläfli symbol of (44;62)(44;64.82), the vertex symbol or long symbol of [4.4.4.4.6(2).6(3)][4.4.4.4.6.6.6(2).6(2).8(13).8(13)], and coordination sequences of (4, 12, 27, 45, 73, 114, 147, 197, 271, 308) for the four-connected nodes and (5, 12, 26, 49, 75, 108, 157, 203, 250, 326) for the five-connected nodes, respectively. This topology represents a (4,5)-connected network .

The La atoms is surrounded by nine oxygen atoms, of which two come from the coordinated water molecules, two from chelating mp ligand, and five from four op ligands. The La–O bond distances range from 2.414 to 2.811<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, which are comparable to those in the related La–carboxylate complexes . Parallel to (0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1), La atoms are bridged by the mp ligands into 2D layers (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig4"></ce:float-anchor>a). The layers are linked by mp ligands into 3D porous structure and the mp ligands act as simply μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-bridges with each of the carboxylate groups chelating one La atom (b).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Structure of [La2(op)2(mp)(H2O)4] n  (5)

Compound 5 is a three-dimensional non-interpenetrated neutral polymeric structure, and the asymmetric unit cell consists of one anionic mp2- ligand, two anionic op2- ligands, four coordinated water molecules and two La(III) atoms. The La atoms is surrounded by nine oxygen atoms, of which two come from the coordinated water molecules, two from chelating mp ligand, and five from four op ligands. The La-O bond distances range from 2.414 to 2.811Å, which are comparable to those in the related La-carboxylate complexes . Parallel to (001), La atoms are bridged by the mp ligands into 2D layers ( a). The layers are linked by mp ligands into 3D porous structure and the mp ligands act as simply μ2-bridges with each of the carboxylate groups chelating one La atom (b).

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Topological analyses show that the framework of <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> consists of four-connected subunits (c). After simplifying the mp group as links between the metal nodes, the four-connected subunits are linked together by the μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-mp bridges to generate a novel (4,5)-connected four-nodal topology (d), where op ligands serve as four-connected nodes and the La atoms as five-connected nodes. The topological network can be described by the Schläfli symbol of (4<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>;6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>;8)(4<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>;6<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>;8<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>)(4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>;6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)(4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>;6<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>). The resulting four-nodal (4,5)-connected 3D topology is novel and unprecedented.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Topological analyses show that the framework of 5 consists of four-connected subunits (c). After simplifying the mp group as links between the metal nodes, the four-connected subunits are linked together by the μ2-mp bridges to generate a novel (4,5)-connected four-nodal topology (d), where op ligands serve as four-connected nodes and the La atoms as five-connected nodes. The topological network can be described by the Schläfli symbol of (43;62;8)(43;64;83)(44;62)(44;66). The resulting four-nodal (4,5)-connected 3D topology is novel and unprecedented.

elements.clean_text:
Luminescence properties

The solid-state fluorescent spectra of 1 and 3 at room temperature are depicted in  . When excited at 380nm under ambient temperature, compound 1 displays strong broad emission peak with the maximum wavelength centered at ca. 448nm, which would likely originate from the ligand-to-ligand     π   L   →   π   L   ∗     charge transfer (LLCT) transition emission; the peaks at 560 and 600nm correspond to the transition of Sm(III) ions from 4G5/2 to 6HJ (J =5/2, 7/2), respectively, the weak intensity and position red-shift of the characteristic emission peaks may be assigned to the radiative decay of of Sm(III) ions under the effect of ligand-to-metal or metal-to-ligand charge transfer (LMCT or MLCT) transition emission . When excited at 350nm, complex 3 exhibits the similar fluorescent behaviors as those of 1, with the maximum wavelength centered at ca. 428nm, and the emission peaks of 558, 596, 642nm attributed to 4G5/2 → 6HJ (J =5/2, 7/2 and 9/2) energy transition, are consistent with the known characteristic emission peaks of Sm(III) ions, respectively. The fluorescent enhancement of the complexes above may be the result of the coordination interactions and crystal packing interactions in the solid by radiationless decay of the intra-ligand or lanthanide ions emission excited state. Complexes 1 and 3 may be used for blue-fluorescent materials. More detailed theoretical and spectroscopic studies are in progress for a better understanding of the luminescent mechanism.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">In summary, four novel mixed node topological nets of lanthanide metal-organic frameworks have been synthesized under hydrothermal reaction. Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits novel (3,4,5,6)-connected two-dimensional five-nodal topological net, compounds <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> show (3,4)-connected V<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf> topologies, compound <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> displays the novel (4,5)-connected three-dimensional topological net, and compound <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> shows the novel (4,5)-connected three-dimensional four-nodal topological network. The work contributes to the discovery of new and previously unrecognized topologies, and affords valuable information for the generation of photoluminescence materials.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, four novel mixed node topological nets of lanthanide metal-organic frameworks have been synthesized under hydrothermal reaction. Compound 1 exhibits novel (3,4,5,6)-connected two-dimensional five-nodal topological net, compounds 2 and 3 show (3,4)-connected V2O5 topologies, compound 4 displays the novel (4,5)-connected three-dimensional topological net, and compound 5 shows the novel (4,5)-connected three-dimensional four-nodal topological network. The work contributes to the discovery of new and previously unrecognized topologies, and affords valuable information for the generation of photoluminescence materials.

Syntheses of the complexes

[Sm2(op)3(H2O)] n  (1)

The mixture of Sm2O3 (0.035g, 0.1mmol), o-phthalic acid (0.05g, 0.3mmol) and H2O (16.0ml) was sealed in a 25ml stainless-steel reactor with Teflon liner and heated to 160°C and kept at constant temperature for 72h, then cooled to room temperature, and the colourless block crystals of 1 were obtained (yield: 37% based on the initial Sm2O3 input). Elemental Anal. Calc. for 1: C, 35.54; H, 1.74. Found: C, 35.73; H, 1.65%. IR data (cm-1, KBr): 3454(w), 3064(w), 1635(m), 1608(s), 1556(vs), 1497(m), 1443(s), 1371(s), 1151(w), 1086(w), 845(m), 744(m), 715(m), 698(m), 652(w), 590(m), 550(m), 449(w).

{[La2(op)2(ox)(H2O)4]⋅H2O} n  (2)

The mixture of La2O3 (0.065g, 0.2mmol), o-phthalic acid (0.083g, 0.5mmol), H2C2O4 ⋅2H2O (0.025g, 0.2mmol) and H2O (16.0ml) was sealed in a 25ml stainless-steel reactor with Teflon liner and heated to 180°C and kept at constant temperature for 72h, then cooled to room temperature, and the colourless crystals of 2 were obtained (yield: 35% based on the initial La2O3 input). Elemental Anal. Calc. for 2: C, 27.57; H, 2.31. Found: C, 27.41; H, 2.20%. IR data (cm-1, KBr): 3356(m), 1659(s), 1626(m), 1520(s), 1493(s), 1454(m), 1423(s), 1404(s), 1306(m), 1151(w), 1090(w), 876(w), 849(m), 793(m), 777(m), 710(m), 658(w), 584(w).

{[Sm2(op)2(ox)(H2O)4]⋅H2O} n  (3)

The procedure was the same as that of 2 except that La2O3 was replaced by the corresponding Sm2O3. The colourless crystals of 3 afforded with the yield about 45% based on the initial Sm2O3 input. Elemental Anal. Calc. for 3: C, 26.79; H, 2.25. Found: C, 26.58; H, 2.17%. IR data (cm-1, KBr): 3576(m), 3334(s), 1664(s), 1628(m), 1581(m), 1522(s), 1497(s), 1456(s), 1431(s), 1410(s), 1311(m), 1151(w), 1092(w), 879(m), 852(m), 796(m), 775(s), 712(m), 658(m), 534(m), 447(w).

{[La2(mp)2(ox)(H2O)4]⋅2H2O} n  (4)

The procedure was the same as that of 2 except that o-phthalic acid was replaced by the corresponding m-phthalic acid. The colourless crystals of 4 afforded with the yield about 35% based on the initial La2O3 input. Elemental Anal. Calc. for 4: C, 26.95; H, 2.51. Found: C, 26.87; H, 2.45%. IR data (cm-1, KBr): 3515(vs), 1649(s), 1614(s), 1564(s), 1527(vs), 1458(m), 1452(s), 1396(vs), 1315(m), 1188(w), 1167(w), 924(w), 829(w), 802(w), 752(w), 712(m), 542(w), 420(w).

[La2(op)2(mp)(H2O)4] n  (5)

The mixture of La2O3 (0.016g, 0.05mmol), La(NO3)3 ⋅6H2O (0.0433g, 0.1mmol), m-phthalic acid (0.017g, 0.1mmol), o-phthalic acid (0.034g, 0.1mmol) and H2O (16.0ml) was sealed in a 25ml stainless-steel reactor with Teflon liner and heated to 160°C and kept at constant temperature for 72h, then cooled to room temperature, and the colourless crystals of 5 were obtained (yield: 30% based on the initial La2O3 and La(NO3)3 ⋅6H2O input). Elemental Anal. Calc. for 5: C, 34.23; H, 2.39. Found: C, 34.18; H, 2.45%. IR data (cm-1, KBr): 3610(w), 3431(m), 3196(w), 1601(m), 1531(vs), 1491(m), 1421(s), 1406(s), 1392(s), 1375(s), 1149(w), 1086(w), 874(w), 841(w), 750(m), 698(w), 652(w), 596(w), 424(w).

Structure of {[La2(mp)2(ox)(H2O)4]⋅2H2O} n  (4)

The asymmetric unit of compound 4 contains one La(III) atom, one mp2- ligand, one-half oxalate group, two coordinated water molecules and one lattice aqua. The central La(III) ion exhibits a square antiprism geometry, surrounded by eight oxygen atoms, of which two come from the coordinated water molecules, two come from one oxalate ligand and four come from four mp ligands. The distances La-O bond range from 2.418 to 2.619Å, which are comparable to those in the related La-carboxylate complexes . The mp ligand in 4 acts as a μ4-bridge linking four metal ions through its four carboxylate O atoms and each metal ion connects four ligands to form a square lattice layers ( a). The layers are interlinked by oxalate ligands into porous 3D metal-organic framework with the lattice water filling in the channels along the b-axis (b). Topological analyses show that the MOFs consist of four-connected subunits (c). After simplifying the oxalate as links between the metal nodes, the four-connected subunits are held together by the μ2-oxalate bridges to generate a new (4,5)-connected topology (d), where μ4-bridging op ligands act as four-connected nodes and the metal atoms serve as five-connected nodes. The topological network can be described by the Schläfli symbol of (44;62)(44;64.82), the vertex symbol or long symbol of [4.4.4.4.6(2).6(3)][4.4.4.4.6.6.6(2).6(2).8(13).8(13)], and coordination sequences of (4, 12, 27, 45, 73, 114, 147, 197, 271, 308) for the four-connected nodes and (5, 12, 26, 49, 75, 108, 157, 203, 250, 326) for the five-connected nodes, respectively. This topology represents a (4,5)-connected network .

Structure of [La2(op)2(mp)(H2O)4] n  (5)

Compound 5 is a three-dimensional non-interpenetrated neutral polymeric structure, and the asymmetric unit cell consists of one anionic mp2- ligand, two anionic op2- ligands, four coordinated water molecules and two La(III) atoms. The La atoms is surrounded by nine oxygen atoms, of which two come from the coordinated water molecules, two from chelating mp ligand, and five from four op ligands. The La-O bond distances range from 2.414 to 2.811Å, which are comparable to those in the related La-carboxylate complexes . Parallel to (001), La atoms are bridged by the mp ligands into 2D layers ( a). The layers are linked by mp ligands into 3D porous structure and the mp ligands act as simply μ2-bridges with each of the carboxylate groups chelating one La atom (b).

Luminescence properties

The solid-state fluorescent spectra of 1 and 3 at room temperature are depicted in  . When excited at 380nm under ambient temperature, compound 1 displays strong broad emission peak with the maximum wavelength centered at ca. 448nm, which would likely originate from the ligand-to-ligand     π   L   →   π   L   ∗     charge transfer (LLCT) transition emission; the peaks at 560 and 600nm correspond to the transition of Sm(III) ions from 4G5/2 to 6HJ (J =5/2, 7/2), respectively, the weak intensity and position red-shift of the characteristic emission peaks may be assigned to the radiative decay of of Sm(III) ions under the effect of ligand-to-metal or metal-to-ligand charge transfer (LMCT or MLCT) transition emission . When excited at 350nm, complex 3 exhibits the similar fluorescent behaviors as those of 1, with the maximum wavelength centered at ca. 428nm, and the emission peaks of 558, 596, 642nm attributed to 4G5/2 → 6HJ (J =5/2, 7/2 and 9/2) energy transition, are consistent with the known characteristic emission peaks of Sm(III) ions, respectively. The fluorescent enhancement of the complexes above may be the result of the coordination interactions and crystal packing interactions in the solid by radiationless decay of the intra-ligand or lanthanide ions emission excited state. Complexes 1 and 3 may be used for blue-fluorescent materials. More detailed theoretical and spectroscopic studies are in progress for a better understanding of the luminescent mechanism.
